questions.question: A baby presents with chronic diarrhea and a rash resembling acrodermatitis on the skin. Based on the clinical picture, what is the most likely deficiency?
questions.explanation: Chronic diarrhea Periorificial and acral dermatitis (rash around the mouth, hands, feet, and perineal area) Alopecia Failure to thrive and immune dysfunction It occurs due to impaired zinc absorption and can also be seen in cases of inadequate dietary intake or prolonged parenteral nutrition without zinc supplementation. Other Options: Selenium deficiency (Option B) : Causes cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease) and muscle weakness , but not chronic diarrhea or acrodermatitis. Niacin deficiency (Option C) : Leads to pellagra , which is characterized by the "3 D’s"— diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia —but the rash is typically photosensitive , unlike acrodermatitis. Magnesium deficiency(Option D) : Presents with neuromuscular symptoms like tetany, seizures, and arrhythmias rather than a characteristic rash and chronic diarrhea. Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology 9 th edition - page 41.1, 63.16, 63.25 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK493187/#article-28798.s7

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents with complaints of multiple soft, pedunculated masses scattered across his torso and limbs. The parents mention that the child has recently developed some difficulty in reading and learning. Upon examination, the child has hyperpigmented macules with irregular borders on his back, and the ocular exam shows the findings below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) NF1 Explanation: The child presents with: Multiple soft, pedunculated masses → Likely neurofibromas Hyperpigmented macules with irregular borders → Café-au-lait spots Ocular findings (likely Lisch nodules on iris examination) Learning difficulties These findings are characteristic of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17, which encodes neurofibromin (a tumor suppressor protein). Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) Incidence: 1 in 3,000 live births. Inheritance: 50% of cases are inherited from a parent. 50% due to spontaneous mutations. Genetics: Autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11.2. The gene encodes neurofibromin, which inhibits the oncogene Ras. Diagnosis Criteria (Two or more required) Feature Description Café-au-lait macules (CALMs) >5 mm in prepubertal, >15 mm in postpubertal. 6 or more needed for diagnosis Axillary/Inguinal Freckling Multiple hyperpigmented areas, 2-3 mm in diameter. Iris Lisch Nodules Hamartomas in the iris, best seen with a slit-lamp. 2 or more needed for diagnosis Neurofibromas Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma. Osseous Lesion Sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones. Congenital pseudarthrosis of the tibia. Optic Gliomas CNS tumor affecting the optic nerve. Family History First-degree relative with an NF1 diagnosis based on these criteria. questions.question: Which of the following mineral deficiency is associated with poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhoea and alopecia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Zinc Zinc deficiency leads to poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia due to its role in cell division, immune function, and tissue repair. Acrodermatitis enteropathica (a genetic disorder of zinc absorption) presents with periorificial and acral dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia . Zinc is crucial for collagen synthesis, immune function, and enzyme activity , making its deficiency detrimental to healing. Zinc Deficiency Feature Zinc Deficiency Causes Poor diet, malabsorption (Crohn’s, celiac), chronic diarrhea, alcoholism Clinical Features Poor wound healing, dermatitis, alopecia, diarrhea, immune dysfunction Dermatological Signs Eczematous plaques, periorificial dermatitis, nail dystrophy Diagnosis Low serum zinc, clinical presentation Treatment Zinc supplementation (oral zinc sulfate) Iron (Option A): Incorrect because iron deficiency causes anemia, fatigue, koilonychia, and glossitis , not dermatitis and diarrhea. Calcium (Option B): Incorrect because calcium deficiency leads to tetany, muscle spasms, and osteomalacia , not alopecia or poor wound healing. Magnesium (Option C): Incorrect because magnesium deficiency causes neuromuscular excitability, tremors, and cardiac arrhythmias , not dermatitis or alopecia. Reference: Vasudevan 7th edition , pg no 497, 522

questions.question: A 50-year-old patient presents with the following skin lesions characterized by red and scaly patches. The patient also complains of a painful and swollen finger joint. On examination, the finger joint appears inflamed and tender to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Psoriatic Arthritis The image shows dactylitis (sausage digit), which is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis (PsA) . The patient has red and scaly skin lesions , suggesting psoriasis . Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis , affecting small and large joints, with dactylitis, enthesitis, and nail changes . Dactylitis is a hallmark feature of PsA , caused by inflammation of both tendons and joints. Psoriatic Arthritis Feature Psoriatic Arthritis Etiology Autoimmune, associated with HLA-B27 Joint Involvement Asymmetrical, affects DIP, PIP, and spine Key Features Dactylitis (sausage digit), enthesitis, nail pitting, onycholysis Skin Lesions Psoriasis (scaly plaques on extensor surfaces) Diagnosis CASPAR criteria , RF negative, elevated ESR/CRP Treatment NSAIDs, DMARDs (Methotrexate, Sulfasalazine), Biologics (TNF- α inhibitors) Pseudo gout (Option B): Incorrect because pseudo gout presents with acute monoarthritis (e.g., knee) due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition , but does not cause dactylitis or skin lesions. Osteoarthritis (Option C): Incorrect because OA affects weight-bearing joints, spares DIP, and lacks systemic inflammation like psoriasis. Reactive Arthritis (Option D): Incorrect because reactive arthritis follows an infection (e.g., GI or GU) and presents with conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis (Reiter’s syndrome) , but lacks dactylitis and psoriasis.

questions.question: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Phrynoderma Explanation: Clinical Presentation: History of night blindness (suggests vitamin A deficiency). Follicular hyperkeratotic papules , typically on extensor surfaces. Classic Appearance: Resembles "toad skin" (hence, phrynoderma ). Associated with malnutrition and vitamin A deficiency . Most Likely Diagnosis: Phrynoderma (Follicular hyperkeratosis due to vitamin A deficiency) . Phrynoderma (Vitamin A Deficiency) Feature Details Definition Follicular hyperkeratosis due to Vitamin A deficiency Causes Malnutrition, fat malabsorption, chronic diarrhea Clinical Features Keratotic papules on extensor surfaces, rough skin, night blindness Diagnosis Clinical, serum Vitamin A levels Treatment Vitamin A supplementation, improved nutrition Keratosis pilaris (Option B): Incorrect because it is a benign genetic condition without a history of vitamin A deficiency . Darier disease (Option C): Incorrect because it presents with greasy crusted papules , not vitamin A-related follicular hyperkeratosis . Follicular eczema (Option D): Incorrect because eczema is associated with itching, scaling , and lichenification , not night blindness. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16918630/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1995140/

questions.question: The following lesion was noticed in a patient with a history of involuntary weight loss. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: patches of skin. These patches often have a velvety texture and can occur in various areas of the body, such as the neck, armpits, groin, and skin folds . Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with insulin resistance, which can be seen in conditions like type 2 diabetes or as a result of obesity. Incorrect options : Option B . Leser-Trélat sign refers to the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, which are benign skin growths. This sign is associated with underlying malignancies, particularly gastrointestinal cancers, but it does not specifically indicate involuntary weight loss. Option C . Actinic keratosis is a precancerous skin condition characterized by rough, scaly patches that develop due to long-term sun exposure. While it can be associated with certain types of skin cancer, it is not directly related to involuntary weight loss. Option D . Intertriginous Candida refers to a fungal infection that occurs in areas of skin-on-skin contact, such as the groin, armpits, or under the breasts. It typically presents as red, itchy, and moist lesions, but it is not typically associated with involuntary weight loss. Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology

questions.question: What is the cause of cutis marmorata?
questions.explanation: condition characterized by a mottled or reticulated appearance of the skin. It occurs due to the dilation of capillaries and venules in response to cold temperature. This is a normal physiological response to cold exposure and is commonly observed in infants and young children. Incorrect Options: Option B - Humidity: Humidity does not directly cause cutis marmorata. However, changes in humidity can sometimes affect the appearance of the skin, particularly in individuals with underlying skin conditions or sensitivities. Option C - Exposure to hot temperature: Cutis marmorata is not typically associated with exposure to hot temperatures. It is more commonly seen in response to cold temperatures. Option D - An adverse reaction to drugs: While certain medications can cause skin reactions, cutis marmorata is not specifically associated with adverse drug reactions. It is primarily related to temperature-induced changes in blood vessel constriction. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?

options.A: The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal
options.B: Erythema and peau d’ orange appearance of the skin be seen
options.C: Can occur in association with diabetes
options.D: Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds phenomenon

questions.explanation: with sclerodactyly or Raynaud's phenomenon." This statement is false. Scleredema is a distinct condition and should not be confused with scleroderma, which is associated with sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers) and Raynaud's phenomenon (vasospasm of blood vessels in response to cold or stress). Incorrect Options: Option A : "The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal." This statement is true for scleredema. Scleredema is characterized by thickening of the dermis, resulting in a firm, indurated texture of the skin. Option B : "Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen." This statement is also true for scleredema. Erythema (redness) and a peau d'orange (orange peel) appearance of the skin are commonly observed in scleredema. Option C : "Scleredema can occur in association with diabetes." This statement is true. Scleredema can be associated with various underlying conditions, including diabetes mellitus. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient came with fever, body ache, and joint pain. He was given NSAIDS. A few days later, he developed brownish pigmentation over the nose. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.explanation: aegypti and Aedes albopictus species. The symptoms of Chikungunya typically include fever, body ache, and joint pain, which are similar to those described in the scenario. One characteristic feature of Chikungunya is the development of brownish pigmentation over the nose, known as "Chikungunya pigmentation." This pigmentation is a specific dermatological manifestation associated with the infection and can occur during the acute or subacute phase of the disease. It is believed to be due to the deposition of hemosiderin, a pigment derived from the breakdown of red blood cells, in the skin. Incorrect Options : Option A Melasma: Melasma is a common skin condition characterized by brownish or grayish pigmentation on the face, particularly on the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. It is typically triggered by hormonal changes, such as during pregnancy or with the use of hormonal contraceptives. Melasma is not directly related to the symptoms described in the scenario or to the use of NSAIDs. Option B Fixed drug eruption (FDE): Fixed drug eruption is a type of drug reaction characterized by the development of well-defined skin lesions after the administration of a particular medication. These lesions typically recur at the same site(s) each time the drug is taken. Brownish pigmentation may occur as part of the healing process, but the key feature of FDE is the recurrent appearance of the lesions at specific locations. The scenario does not mention any recurring skin lesions associated with drug intake, making FDE an unlikely diagnosis. Option C Dengue: Dengue is another viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, particularly the Aedes mosquito. The symptoms of dengue include fever, body ache, and joint pain, which are similar to those described in the scenario. However, the development of brownish pigmentation over the nose is not a characteristic feature of dengue. Instead, dengue is known for causing other dermatological manifestations, such as a rash and red spots on the skin. Reference: .

questions.question: A mother has a pearly white papule on her forehead which her infant also develops. What is the cause?
questions.explanation: suggestive of a condition called Molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by the Pox virus. Molluscum contagiosum is a common viral skin infection that primarily affects children, but it can also occur in adults. Molluscum contagiosum presents as small, flesh-colored or pearly white papules on the skin. These papules often have a central depression or "dimple" and can appear anywhere on the body, including the forehead. The infection is highly contagious and can be transmitted through direct skin-to-skin contact or by sharing personal items like towels or clothing. Incorrect options: Option A) HPV (Human Papillomavirus): While HPV can cause various types of skin lesions, including warts, it is not typically associated with pearly white papules on the forehead resembling Molluscum contagiosum. HPV commonly causes genital warts, plantar warts, and common warts on hands or feet, but it is not the primary cause of Molluscum contagiosum. Option C) Adenovirus: Adenovirus is a common respiratory virus that can cause a range of symptoms, including respiratory infections, conjunctivitis (pink eye), and gastroenteritis. questions.question: A child patient comes to OPD with history of black central arch rashes on his body , what is your diagnosis ?
questions.explanation: meningitidis. It is characterized by the presence of a petechial or purpuric rash, which appears as black central arch rashes on the body. The rash occurs due to small areas of bleeding under the skin, known as petechiae, that darken over time. Incorrect option Option B , Dengue hemorrhagic fever: Dengue fever is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. While it can cause a rash, it typically presents as a maculopapular rash that is not characterized by black central arch rashes. Additionally, dengue hemorrhagic fever is a severe form of dengue that involves bleeding, but the rash pattern described in the question is not associated with dengue hemorrhagic fever. Option C , Leptospirosis: Leptospirosis is a bacterial infection caused by the spirochete bacteria of the genus Leptospira. It can cause a range of symptoms, including fever, muscle pain, and rash. However, the rash in leptospirosis is typically a maculopapular rash and does not typically present as black central arch rashes. Option D , Scrub typhus: Scrub typhus is an infectious disease caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi. It is transmitted through the bite of infected mites. The characteristic rash in scrub typhus is an eschar, which is a dark, crusted lesion at the site of the mite bite. It does not typically present as black central arch rashes.
